Title: Swedish Rectal Prolapse Trial: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Background: The optimal surgical approach for rectal prolapse remains uncertain. This trial aimed to compare outcomes of different surgical approaches.

Methods: This multicentre randomised controlled trial was conducted across 13 sites in Sweden from March 2000 to May 2009. Participants with full-thickness rectal prolapse were randomised to either a perineal or abdominal approach (randomisation A), or to Delorme’s vs. Altemeier’s (randomisation B) or suture vs. resection rectopexy (randomisation C) based on suitability. Randomisation was performed using concealed envelopes in blocks of four. Primary outcomes were bowel function and quality of life (QoL) measured by Wexner incontinence score and RAND-36 over 3 years. Secondary outcomes included recurrence and complications. Blinding was not applied.

Results: A total of 134 patients were randomised: 18 in randomisation A, 80 in B, and 54 in C. Of these, 122 underwent surgery and were analysed per-protocol. Mean follow-up was 2.6 years. Improvements in Wexner and RAND-36 scores were observed, but no significant differences between groups. Health change scores improved significantly up to 1 year (P < 0.001). Recurrence rates at 3 years were higher for perineal vs. abdominal approaches and Delorme’s vs. Altemeier’s, but differences were not significant. No significant differences in complications were noted.

Interpretation: All procedures showed significant health improvements post-surgery, but recurrence rates were higher than previously reported. Trial registration: NCT04893642. Funding: Not specified.
